newsitem.title: JAPAN: TIFFE Euroyen end up as interest swap rates fall.
newsitem.headline: TIFFE Euroyen end up as interest swap rates fall.

text.p: Key June three-month Euroyen futures ended higher on Wednesday due to a fall in interest rate swap (IRS) rates, particularly near the three-year zone, traders said.
The three-year IRS rate was quoted at 1.27/1.31 percent as of 0717 GMT, down sharply from around 1.46 percent in early afternoon trade on Tuesday.
A trader at a long-term credit bank said city banks and foreign banks had received three-year fixed interest rates late on Tuesday, which triggered the steep fall in the IRS rate.
A city bank trader said those who received floating interest rates, who were on the other side of these trades, bought Euroyen futures for hedging purposes.

"Nobody wants to receive floating interest rates except for arbitrageurs, who are buying Euroyen futures to hedge their positions. Such buying is encouraging day traders to buy as well, creating a demand-driven market," the trader said.
Trading volume of the June Euroyen futures was 80,677 contracts.
Traders said the weighted average of the key overnight call rate was likely to be 0.49 percent on Wednesday.
Traders said there was upward pressure on the overnight call rate as fund demand remained strong ahead of the end of the current bank reserves reporting period on Friday.
The Bank of Japan injected a net 600 billion yen into the money market this morning, maintaining its neutral stance.
The BOJ is likely to maintain its neutral stance for the time being, a trader for another city bank said.
About 30 billion yen worth of the key three-month certificates of deposit (CDs) were issued on Wednesday, at 0.52 percent.
One- and two-month CDs were tagged with sell quotes of 0.49 percent and 0.50 percent, respectively. -- Tokyo Treasury Desk +81-3-5473-3748
